STRAYED.
About two months ago a black cow
was stolen from Mr. Smith, located near
the town of Prince Albert.
She has been missing ever since.
If found, please return her to
Mr. Smith.

Biscuits, Cakes,
Nuts, Candies of all kinds.
Green Apples,
Canned Meats,
Connect Fruits,
Canadian and American.
Choice Dairies & Marilla Cherries
Wholesale and Retail.

R. T. GOODFELLOW.
Prince Albert, N.W.T.

PUBLIC NOTICE.
It is hereby given to all concerned that repay-
ment of the amount advanced by Mr. Smith
will be made immediately.
The amount advanced will be returned to Mr. Smith
within thirty days.
Any person who fails to make repayment within
this time will be held liable for the full amount.
Mr. Smith is willing to accept any reasonable
terms of repayment.

SEED GRAIN.
A large selection of seeds will be available
at the Royal Mail Store.
Orders may be placed now for delivery in December.
The store is located at the corner of Main Street
and Second Avenue.

TEACHER WANTED.
Teacher wanted for the Prince Albert
Public School.
Applications must be made by December 1st.
The salary will be $100 per month.
Address: CHAS. WOODMAN,
Prince Albert, N.W.T.

ROBERT THOMSON,
Sign & Ornamental Painter
Calsominin and Paperhang-
ing on short notice.
Decorative Painting a Specialty.

A. C. PATTERSON,
Forwarding Agent.
(By Special Telegraph)
The Northwest Council has been pro-
posed in connection with the Red River
Question.
A report was adopted to be forwarded to the
Government of Canada regarding the
situation in Prince Albert district.

CHIT-CHAT ICCALS.
Gathered by our Reporters.

Weather fine.
Shooting fine.
Try Tom Davis' Pure Java Coffee.
J. M. Hay arrived by last Mon-
day night.
R. C. Wigmore has received a large
stock of fancy goods.
The P. A. C. ban takes place to-night.
T. J. Agnew purchased a large stock of
general hardware the week.
Judge McLeod on his way to Prince
Albert.
The P. A. C. Band will take place
tonight at the Queen's.
Peter Hartsell, chief interpreter for
the Indian Department, is here.
The annual meeting of the Court will
take place in the new courthouse.
Rev. Mr. Hilton will preach next Sun-
day afternoon at St. John's church.
The number of students attending
the Mission school has increased to 50.
A sale of turkeys and geese will take
place Saturday night at the Queen's.
Miss Macpherson, sister of Mrs. Dr.
Porter, and Miss Miller, arrived by last
mail.
Ladies' Jackets, Gloves and Belts in
abundance at Tom Davis'.
The sale of Susan Macpherson's effects
was well attended and good prices were
obtained.
Ladies', Girls' and Children's Shapery,
Hosiery and Trim Work at
T. O. Porter's.

PUBLIC NOTICE.
The Indian office has been removed to
the new building, next door west
of the telegraph office.
At a meeting of the School Board for
District No. 3, which took place last
night, Mr. John Stewart was elected
chairman.
No show for lottery. Just try Tom
Davis' Tea.
Rev. Dr. Hartley preached his first
sermon here last Sunday evening, to a large
congregation. He created a very favor-
able impression.
This Again, we are happy to say,
there is no lack of business in the firm
in Battilford, even deputies represented.
His sales will exceed $500.
Mr. McCafferty, Land Agent, arrived
here by the last mail. He visited the
school and shops during his absence and
will, altogether, enjoy a very pleasant
holiday.
A cook of the Saskatchewan Curling
Club has been engaged to cook the dinner
on the river on Thanksgiving Day. A
number of students also enjoyed them-
selves.
Eighteen in Fine Oatmeal for 4¢ at
Tom Davis'.
Mr. McCafferty's operation at St. Laurent,
which has been here for some time, is,
we are happy to say, improving, and will shortly
be completed successfully.
The City Hall has been sub-
jected to thorough overhauling and
all public tables have been covered.
Mr. McCafferty's operation, which is
a guarantee that the place will be conducted
in a thoroughly prompt manner.
The man who bought a pair of Tom
Davis' Boots and Pants never worked
at the Courthouse.
Mr. Wadsworth, of the Indian Depart-
ment, went to John Smith's residence
last night and returned yesterday.
He reports that the Indians had broken out of their
quarters and were about to break into
the school, but that the chief had built himself a new house
while there he visited the school on the
river and spoke with Mr. McCafferty.
About thirty Indian children
are attending it, and all are making
rapid progress in their studies.
FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1886.

THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW,
PUBLISHED BY
J. D. MAEVETTY
PRINCE ALBERT, N.W.T.

FRIDAY, NOV. 19, 1886.

THE LATE BISHOP MCLAREN.

By the death of the Bishop of Saskatchew an, we have lost a man of great humanity has been cast over the whole district where he had so widely diffused his untiring energy in the cause of "light and learning." The news of his decease came upon us like a bolt from the blue, and for the people amongst whom his lot had been cast, had so subordinated himself to their welfare, he will be truly missed. The land of his adoption was the land of his love—his whole life was consecrated to its welfare, and good of those amongst whom he laboured and he devoted his great abilities, his time and his life to promote their highest interests.

The late prelate was a man of high scholastic attainments. He was well versed in his subject, and his knowledge of the Bible was profound. He was a man of rare ability and a teacher of young men he had few superiors. We shall miss him greatly.

We shall miss him greatly.

ST. ANNE'S ACADEMY, who was the first Lady Governor of Madras, made a speech at the meeting in Toronto, Ont., on the question in which he showed the position the Liberals are in regard to the Roman Catholics. After stating that Blake was arrested for the arrest of Blake, characterising him as a "traitor and a drunkard," he said something to the effect that the Liberal party was a "villain, millions a hero."

"A CARNIVAL Conservative," writing to the Toronto Globe, says—Any person who conceives that Mr. Mercer is a Roman Catholic, or that any party proposition is a foolish mistake, is a fool. Mr. Mercer does not prefer Protestant to Roman, but he likes both parties equally. Any person who says that Mr. Mercer is a Roman Catholic is either a fool or a liar. They presumed that the assumption that Mr. Mercer was a fool and they are not far wrong.

THE LAST SAD RITES.
FUNERAL OF THE LATE RIGHT REV. JOHN NOLAN, BISHOP OF SASKATCHEWAN.

A PUBLIC TRIBUTE TO DEPARTED WORTH.

SERMON BY ARCHBISHOP M'CAVY.

On Sunday last all that was mortal of the late Right Rev. John Nolan was laid to rest in the grandeur attesting his rank at St. Mary's church, and within short distance of Emmanuel College. Tonight at five o'clock, died the day previous, owing to the absence of members of his family and their friends. In about an hour thereafter, came the mourners—more than thirty of them, including the Bishop himself, until the final departure of our chief and nearest relative until the soul has already passed away. It has been marked by deep sorrow, by intense compassion with heartfelt sympathy this day on the part of his fellow-men. May He, the head shepherd of our Church, bless all these things and make us once more to experience that which we have lost. So also to those who have passed from this world, may He comfort and make ease in his great mercy and love.

PRAYERS AND BREVIARY IN USE.

No knell was heard. Our Lord's prayers were read, and the burial rite performed. The coffin was placed in the ground, and then solemnly closed by the hand that had raised it. "And the peace of the Lord be with you always," said the Bishop as he walked away. And there was silence.

By appointment Mr. J. R. Sharp took charge of the ceremonies at Emmanuel Church. Mr. Sharp said that in view of the circumstances, allusion should be made to the death of the Bishop, and that the grave should be dug for him at the church. Mr. Sharp said that he had been instructed by Mr. M'Nary, who was present at the time, that the Bishop should be interred in the grave where he died last week. North West Council

REGINA, Nov 1.

Mr. Second presented a petition from most of the residents of Regina asking for a new alteration in the game laws. It was referred to the committee.

A committee was appointed to obtain information and report on the losses sustained through the ravages of prairie fires.

Mr. Second asked leave to introduce an ordinance amending the game ordinance which was adopted and read a first time. It was to change the close season sale and purchase from August 1st to the 15th August.

Mr. Hughes moved that a committee be appointed to prepare a memorial to the Dominion government asking that a bridge be built over the Saskatchewan River, and extended the motion which was carried.

Judge Richardson called attention to another subject, the driving of carts, and with regard to the printing of the Civil Justice Bill, and denied that the printer was to blame for its delay. Judge Richardson said that the printer was not to blame either.

Mr. Hughes gave notice that he would tender his memorial for a committee to prepare a memorial to the Dominion Government, asking it to grant pensions to the widows and orphans of Prince Albert volunteers killed in the rebellion, and also to those who were wounded at the same time.

NOV. 2.

In the North West Council to-day, Mr. Hughes moved that a select committee be appointed to prepare a memorial to the Dominion government making it to grant pension to the widows and orphan of Prince Albert volunteers killed in the rebellion, and also to those who were wounded at the same time.

Mr. Hughes—Your honour—I prefer to refer to a select committee.

It will accordingly go before the committee.

Mr. Terriff introduced an ordinance to incorporate friendly societies in the Northwest Territories.

It provides that where fifty persons have been united together for the purpose of aiding each other in sickness, and in case any of them may become incapacitated and unable to earn a living by ordinary means, they shall be entitled to assist such as may be needed.

The ordinance gives power to acquire and possess real estate, and dispose of the same for the benefit of the society.

After some discussion the bill was laid on the table.

Some changes were made in the Civil Justice Bill.

NOV. 3.

Mr. Hughes presented a petition from the Royal City Council of Prince Albert, asking that the incorporation of the town be legalized. It was referred to the civil justice committee.

There remains matters for the legalization of everything done by the Council, and some steps are taken toward the granting of medals to the Northwest Mounted Police engaged in their services, whereupon the President made the following remarks:

"We are very much obliged to Mr. Hughes."

Mr. Terriff introduced an ordinance to incorporate friendly societies in the Northwest Territories.

It provides that where fifty persons have been united together for the purpose of aiding each other in sickness, and in case any of them may become incapacitated and unable to earn a living by ordinary means, they shall be entitled to assist such as may be needed.

The ordinance gives power to acquire and possess real estate, and dispose of the same for the benefit of the society.

After some discussion the bill was laid on the table.

Some changes were made in the Civil Justice Bill.

NOV. 4.

Mr. Terriff moved for the incorporation of friendly societies in the Prince Albert volunteers killed at Dust Lake. The petition mentions the names of six killed and wounded, and short life sketches of several of them. The petition was referred.

The house then went into committee of the whole on the ordinance respecting incorporation of friendly societies and congregations. The bill consisted of eleven clauses. No congregation had until recently approved or passed the measure, and there were no objections raised to it excepting those that could be met by some little amendment to the bill.
